parts:
A solutions-based sales call is a sales methodology that revolves around the concept of understanding and addressing a prospect's specific needs with suitable products or services. Emerging in the late 1970s by Michael Bosworth, it marked a significant shift in the sales industry by focusing on solutions to the customer's problems and pain points instead of just the features and benefits of a product or service【6†source】.

This approach is consultative; it involves the salesperson taking the time to deeply understand the customer's problem. By doing so, they can align their sales process with the prospect's buying cycle and suggest a product or service that can genuinely resolve the customer's issue【8†source】.

Emphasizing empathy and active listening, solution selling enables sales professionals to develop personalized solutions that work best for individual customers. This customer-centric method ensures that the sales process is not about hard selling but about building a relationship based on trust and understanding, offering a solution that genuinely fits the customer's needs【10†source】.

content.text:
quote_lines(44, 44)

Solution selling is the process of selling the customer a solution to their problems as opposed to a product or service. The term is associated with the sales of products and services that can be used as the building blocks of a custom implementation. Solution selling is common in areas such as construction services, software and outsourcing sales. The following are the basic stages of a solution selling process.
content.title: The 7 Stages of the Solution Selling Process - Simplicable

content.text:
## 【27†Relationship Building】

Solution selling often involves 【28†complex】, high value sales that take significant time from the cultivation of relationships to close. This requires a stable and highly connected sales team that can develop a large pipeline of prospects and opportunities.
content.title: The 7 Stages of the Solution Selling Process - Simplicable

content.text:
## Consultative Sales 

In order to keep the customer engaged, the sales team may provide access to consultants who can answer the customer's questions and provide valuable industry data such as 【34†benchmarks】. Ideally, the customer becomes dependent on you as a source of knowledge and data.
content.title: The 7 Stages of the Solution Selling Process - Simplicable

content.text:
## 【40†Needs Analysis】

Working with the customer to identify their 【41†needs】, 【42†preferences】 and 【43†perceptions】 to develop a 【44†value proposition】. This is a process of 【45†requirements elicitation】 whereby the customer outlines issues and the sales team captures 【46†requirements】. This will take into account factors such as budget, decision making authority and influencers such that the value proposition is likely to sell.
content.title: The 7 Stages of the Solution Selling Process - Simplicable

content.text:
## Solution Design 

Developing a design that demonstrates how your products and services will solve the customer's problems. A high-level design may be necessary to close a deal. Alternatively, design may be part of solution delivery if your customer is willing to buy based on value proposition alone.
content.title: The 7 Stages of the Solution Selling Process - Simplicable

content.text:
## 【15†Closing】

The process of negotiating price and terms to close a sale. In complex, high-value sales it is common to use a 【55†foot-in-the door】 approach whereby an initial deal solves a single high impact problem for the customer.
content.title: The 7 Stages of the Solution Selling Process - Simplicable

content.text:
## Solution Delivery 

Delivering your obligations to the customer. The goal of solution sales is typically to expand such that the customer is dependent on your products, services and expertise. As such, solution delivery continues to be a sales process whereby 【33†customer relationships】, 【40†needs analysis】, solution design and negotiation of more deals is ongoing.
content.title: The 7 Stages of the Solution Selling Process - Simplicable

content.text:
## 【23†Account Management】

When the solution is launched the account continues to be monitored for 【66†cross-selling】 and 【67†upselling】 opportunities. If you are generating 【68†monthly recurring revenue】, 【69†customer satisfaction】 may be carefully monitored and managed. For example, a sales account manager may contact the customer after an issue or incident to act as a 【70†advocate for the customer】.
content.title: The 7 Stages of the Solution Selling Process - Simplicable

parts:
The processes involved in a solution-based sales call typically include the following stages:

1. **Relationship Building**: Establishing connections with potential customers, which is crucial for complex and high-value sales that require a stable and well-connected sales team【19†source】.

2. **Consultative Sales**: Engaging customers by providing access to consultants who offer valuable industry data and knowledge, aiming to make the customer reliant on the sales team as a source of information【20†source】.

3. **Needs Analysis**: Collaborating with the customer to identify their needs, preferences, and perceptions, and developing a value proposition tailored to these requirements【21†source】.

4. **Solution Design**: Creating a design or plan that showcases how the products or services offered will address the customer's problems【22†source】.

5. **Closing**: Negotiating the price and terms to finalize the sale, often using a "foot-in-the-door" strategy to address a significant problem for the customer with the initial deal【23†source】.

6. **Solution Delivery**: Fulfilling the agreed-upon solution, with the aim of making the customer dependent on the provided products, services, and expertise. This stage is iterative as it may involve continuous customer relationship management and further needs analysis【24†source】.

7. **Account Management**: Monitoring the account for additional sales opportunities like cross-selling and upselling, managing customer satisfaction, and serving as an advocate for the customer post-sale【25†source】.

These stages outline a strategic approach focused on addressing the customer's specific problems with personalized solutions, rather than selling a generic product or service【18†source】.
